elements.text: Alphabet Cards Hh and Qq, large sheets of drawing paper, art supplies
makes the /h/ sound you hear in the words
Ask children to name other words that begin like
makes the /kw/ sound you hear in the words
Ask children to name other words that begin like
Who wants to draw a Happy Hippo?
Who wants to draw the Queen’s Quilt?
Ask each child what they want to draw and label the top of the page for them. If a child wants to draw both, use the front and back of the paper.
As children draw, stop and ask them to name the letter that begins each word in the label at the top of the page.
Children may enjoy tracing over dotted letters, writing letters in the air, or making letters in a sand or salt tray.

Before children draw, make sure they know what they plan to draw. Help them by making shapes for them if they need assistance. Then help children trace with their finger the target letters in the label.

When children name words that begin with the same letter as the pictured word, see how many they can name. Give clues and see if children can name the word that begins with the sound based on the clues you say.
Remember that in Spanish, the letter

is always silent. Exaggerate the movements of your mouth as you form the letter sound. Help children notice the puff of air when they produce the /h/ sound. Do this as you say the sound in isolation and again as you say the sound within the picture word. Invite children to move their mouths in the same way as you repeat each letter sound.
does not have a unique phoneme. The sound that
stands for is represented by the letters /kw/. Children may confuse the sounds for letters
. Help them notice the puff of air when they produce the /kw/ sound.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
One 6-inch white paper circle, crumpled tissue paper in red and white, white glue
It was about a girl who planned to make the world’s biggest fruit salad. And she did!
We talked about making a plan. We saw how important it is to set a goal and then follow steps until you reach that goal.
Let’s make a paper pizza!  Just like Nita, let’s make a plan. Let’s think about the steps we need to follow.
Put down a large circle for the pizza.
Cover it with dots of glue.
Add red tissue paper for the sauce.
Add white tissue paper for the cheese.
Give each child a large paper circle and collections of crumpled red tissue paper and white tissue paper. Say:
Follow each step as I say it until you have a pizza.
Read the directions from above and have children follow them one at a time. Children may need help with covering their large circles with glue so the tissue paper will stick.
After children complete the pizza, review the plan you made and followed.
Talk about why it was helpful to have a plan. Encourage children to name other things they might make a plan for and then do.

Making a plan involves a sequence of steps, which may be challenging for younger children. Take the time to model your thinking aloud about what needs to get done and how. Use sequence words to focus on what happens first, next, then, and last.
Challenge children to add other steps for completing the paper pizza. For example, they might want to cut out and paste circles for pepperoni or thin rectangles for peppers.

Children whose home language is not English may not understand what each step entails. Make sure when you model the steps that these children know what is expected. You might want them to repeat or rephrase each step after you say it.

Some children will need help with this activity. Coat the paper plate with glue for them. Have them put down the red tissue paper. If tissue paper is too difficult to work with, provide red and white construction paper squares instead.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Activity Cards, two paper plates, marker
Nita wants to make the world’s biggest fruit salad. Many people give her fruit and help her cut up the fruit for her healthy fruit salad.

Today we’ll look at pictures and decide if they show one fruit or two fruits. Let’s look at pictures of fruit and sort  them. Let’s put each picture that shows one fruit in this pile. Let’s put each picture that shows two fruits in this pile.
Place two separate paper plates on the table. Write the word
on one plate. Write the word
Show an Activity Card. Ask children to identify what fruit they see. Then ask the child to decide if the picture shows one fruit or two.
Have children continue taking turns turning over a card, naming the food, and noting if they see one or two fruits.
After all the cards are sorted, name all the fruits in the first pile.
All of these pictures show one fruit.
Then name all the fruits in the second pile.
All of these pictures show two fruits.
Invite children to look around the room and name things that they see two or more than two of, for example, “I see two windows,” “I see three doors,” or “I see many pictures.”

If children need help using plurals, use concrete classroom objects to model. For example, show a crayon and present a short sentence: Here is a crayon. Display two crayons and use the plural: Here are two crayons. Model with other available items.

Challenge children to draw their own sets of pictures of vegetables. Have them draw a picture that shows one and then a picture that shows two of each vegetable they name, for example, one carrot, two carrots. Then help children label their pictures.

Ask multilingual learners to share the names of these and other  fruits in their home languages. Encourage them to describe how different types of fruits look and taste. Children whose first language is Spanish will recognize the Spanish cognate
. Help children make this connection if they have not done so already. Making this connection will help to enable their participation in the activity.
To help children with auditory discrimination, exaggerate the final /s/ of plural words. Have children do the same as they repeat plural forms of words.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Big Chart The Voice in Rabbit’s House, paper pointer made from rolled paper with star at the end, stars printed with the sentence, “I am a storyteller.”
Today we read a tale called The Voice in Rabbit’s House. We met wonderful characters—a caterpillar, a rabbit, a leopard, and a rhinoceros. And then we met a very wise frog.
Let’s look at the Big Chart again. When it’s your turn, you will be the storyteller. You will take the storyteller pointer and point to a picture. You can tell us all what is happening.
Display the Big Chart. Read aloud the story. Then have children take turns using the storyteller pointer to point to a picture and tell what is happening.
Take the pointer. Look at the picture and point to it. What is happening now?
Encourage the child to tell as much as they can about what is happening.
Repeat until every child has had a chance to be the storyteller. Then give each child a star that says, “I’m a storyteller.”
Invite children to talk about listening to stories.
Do you like to listen to stories using the headphones in the library corner? Do you like to listen to stories at the library? Do you like to listen to stories your family members tell?
Children may need help with telling about the picture they see. Encourage them with prompts, such as,
What animal is in this picture? What is Rabbit doing? Why are the animals laughing?
Challenge children to name other stories they have heard. Prompt them with questions such as,
Do you know a story that is about three bears? Do you know a story that is about a fox?  Do you know a story that is about a lion?

Ask multilingual learners to share the names of stories they like to listen to in their home languages. Some of the stories may be similar to stories they heard in English and some may not be. Ask children to share some details from the stories they like.

Encourage children’s speech development with prompts that encourage their use of specific nouns and verbs. When storytelling, if a child refers to something in the picture, make sure the child can name the object. Help children use more vivid verbs to describe actions that tell what is happening in each picture.
